title: 109_s4121
content: The curr_chunk is a section titled "TREATMENT OF LIABILITY FOR CERTAIN MULTIPLE EMPLOYER PLANS." The curr_chunk discusses the election for an eligible employer to spin off liability for an applicable pension plan. If the employer elects, the plan's assets and liabilities are transferred to an eligible spunoff plan, and the employer's liability is determined based on the spunoff plan. The curr_chunk explains how the allocation of assets and liabilities for an eligible spunoff plan is determined, and the employer's liability is based on the spunoff plan. The ongoing funding liability for an eligible spunoff plan is exempt from certain provisions until the plan ceases to be eligible. The Pension Protection Act of 2006 does not apply to plan years before the plan ceases to be an eligible spunoff plan. The employer is responsible for ongoing contributions to the spunoff plan based on pre-amendment laws, instead of other liabilities to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation or the pension plan. The Pension Protection Act of 2006 does not apply to plan years before the plan ceases to be an eligible spunoff plan. The employer is responsible for ongoing contributions to the spunoff plan based on pre-amendment laws, instead of other liabilities to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation or the pension plan. In applying certain sections of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act and the Internal Revenue Code to an eligible spunoff plan, the interest rate is determined based on specific criteria. The Pension Protection Act of 2006 does not apply to plan years before the plan ceases to be an eligible spunoff plan. If an eligible spunoff plan terminates before December 31, 2010, the employer's liability will be determined according to specific methods under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act. The liability of an employer for a terminated pension plan under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is determined based on specific methods. If an eligible employer does not elect to spin off the plan, they will be liable to the corporation instead of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation or the pension plan. An eligible employer not making the election described in subsection (b) will be liable to the corporation for the applicable pension plan's adjusted unfunded benefit liabilities as of December 31, 2005. Adjusted unfunded benefit liabilities are determined based on specific methods outlined in the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The term "fractional portion" refers to a fraction representing the employer's contributions to a pension plan compared to all employers who did not make a specific election. The term "applicable pension plan" refers to a single employer plan established in Alaska on March 18, 1967, with 2 or more contributing sponsors as of January 1, 2005. The "allocable portion" is the portion of liabilities and assets in the plan that corresponds to an eligible employer's share. The "allocable portion" is the portion of an applicable pension plan's liabilities and assets that corresponds to an eligible employer's share in the plan. An eligible employer is defined as an employer that participated in an eligible multiple employer plan on or after January 1, 2000.
